docs.snippet: President Andrés Pastrana warned Colombian rebels to ''make progress'' in setting up a timetable for talks about a cease-fire. ''Negotiating in the middle of the conflict has finished,'' he said, ''and we need progress quickly.'' Mr. Pastrana has...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Andrés Pastrana warned Colombian rebels to ''make progress'' in setting up a timetable for talks about a cease-fire. ''Negotiating in the middle of the conflict has finished,'' he said, ''and we need progress quickly.'' Mr. Pastrana has until Sunday to decide whether to renew the rebel hold on a huge demilitarized zone ceded to them by the government three years ago. Mr. Pastrana's words came three days after he and the rebels agreed to talk about a cease-fire, a deal that came after five days of tense negotiations aimed at patching up stalled efforts toward peace. Juan Forero (NYT)
docs.abstract: Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia warns Colombian rebels of need for progess in quickly setting up timetable for cease-fire (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Pastrana Urges Steps To Peace

docs.snippet: A 12-year-old Colombian boy, whose deathbed plea to see his kidnapped father touched this war-weary nation, died of cancer today, provoking fresh outrage at rebels who snubbed the boy's wish, relatives said.    Andrés Felipe Pérez died at his ho...
docs.lead_paragraph: A 12-year-old Colombian boy, whose deathbed plea to see his kidnapped father touched this war-weary nation, died of cancer today, provoking fresh outrage at rebels who snubbed the boy's wish, relatives said. Andrés Felipe Pérez died at his home in the southern city of Buga after suffering a respiratory crisis, doctors said.
docs.abstract: Andres Felipe Perez, 12, whose deathbed plea to see his kidnapped policeman father Norberto Perez touched war-weary Colombia, dies of cancer; death spurs fresh outrage at rebels who snubbed his wish; photo (M)

headline.main: Boy Who Moved Colombia, Not Rebels, Dies

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Nicholas D. Kristof's idea of suing Saddam Hussein for crimes against humanity committed against his own people (''Try Suing Saddam,'' column, March 26) is a good one. Rather than establishing an ad hoc international tribunal for...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof's idea of suing Saddam Hussein for crimes against humanity committed against his own people (''Try Suing Saddam,'' column, March 26) is a good one. Rather than establishing an ad hoc international tribunal for his crimes or charging Iraq at the International Court of Justice, Mr. Kristof suggests having a national court indict him under universal jurisdiction for crimes against humanity.
docs.abstract: David Bach letter on Mar 28 Nicholas D Kristof article encourages United States to ratify International Criminal Court and try Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein in that forum for crimes against humanity

docs.snippet: Gunmen killed Archbishop Isaías Duarte Cancino in Calí today, silencing a voice that had often been critical of leftist rebels. The archbishop had just completed a group wedding when he was shot outside a church, witnesses said. No one immediate...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gunmen killed Archbishop Isaías Duarte Cancino in Calí today, silencing a voice that had often been critical of leftist rebels. The archbishop had just completed a group wedding when he was shot outside a church, witnesses said. No one immediately claimed responsibility. Archbishop Duarte Cancino was dead on arrival at the Trujillo Hospital, the hospital director, Ricardo Vanegas, said. Edilberto Ceballos, the archbishop's driver, said the prelate was shot several times.
docs.abstract: Gunmen kill Archbishop Isaias Duarte Cancino in Cali, Colombia, silencing voice that had often been critical of leftist rebels (S)

headline.main: Gunmen Kill Bishop In Colombian City

docs.snippet: Soldiers have killed 11 Maoist rebels and detained 22 suspected separatists in the past 48 hours, the Defense Ministry said in a statement, hours after a Katmandu bombing attributed to the Maoists. They have recently stepped up their violent campa...
docs.lead_paragraph: Soldiers have killed 11 Maoist rebels and detained 22 suspected separatists in the past 48 hours, the Defense Ministry said in a statement, hours after a Katmandu bombing attributed to the Maoists. They have recently stepped up their violent campaign ahead of the sixth anniversary of the start of their revolt, which seeks to topple Nepal's constitutional monarchy and set up a one-party Communist republic. The guerrillas broke a truce and walked out of peace talks last year.
docs.abstract: Defense Ministry in Nepal says soldiers have killed 11 Maoist rebels and detained 22 suspected separatists in past 48 hours; makes statement hours after Katmandu bombing attributed to Maoists (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Separatists Killed

docs.snippet: A bicycle bomb exploded outside a packed Bogotá restaurant frequented by the Colombian police, killing four officers and a little girl in an attack that the government attributed to rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. Fourteen p...
docs.lead_paragraph: A bicycle bomb exploded outside a packed Bogotá restaurant frequented by the Colombian police, killing four officers and a little girl in an attack that the government attributed to rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. Fourteen people were wounded in the noontime blast. Police officials also found and disarmed two other bombs in the city, concluding that the rebels had attempted a coordinated attack. Despite an accord reached with the government last weekend pledging to reach a cease-fire deal by April 17, the rebels have stepped up attacks in recent weeks.
docs.abstract: Bomb explodes outside packed, Bogota restaurant frequented by Colombian police, killing four officers and child and wounding 14 people; government blames rebel group; police also find and disarm two other bombs in city (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Bomb Kills 5 In Bogotá

docs.snippet: The authorities in Dagestan, a republic in southern Russia, said they had released 10 people, including a former member of Russia's Parliament, who had been detained in connection with a bombing attack in neighboring Chechnya that killed at least ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The authorities in Dagestan, a republic in southern Russia, said they had released 10 people, including a former member of Russia's Parliament, who had been detained in connection with a bombing attack in neighboring Chechnya that killed at least seven Russian soldiers. A spokesman for the Dagestan branch of the Russian F.S.B. security service said the former member of Parliament, Nadirshakh Khachilayev had no connection to the bombing. The Dagestan prosecutor's office said he had been charged with illegal possession of weapons and explosives found at his home.
docs.abstract: Authorities in Dagestan Republic in southern Russia say they released 10 people who had been detained in connection with bombing attack in neighboring Chechnya that killed at least seven Russian soldiers (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 10 Held In Bombing Freed

docs.snippet: To the Editor: Reading ''Where Churchill Waged War, Underground'' (Dec. 16), by Anne Roiphe, brought back memories of the War Office headquarters for Britain, which was nearby and featured an underground labyrinth of rooms and tunnels.    I was 18...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Reading ''Where Churchill Waged War, Underground'' (Dec. 16), by Anne Roiphe, brought back memories of the War Office headquarters for Britain, which was nearby and featured an underground labyrinth of rooms and tunnels. I was 18, working there in 1944-45 as a radio and teleprinter operator for the War Office Signals (communications) department.
docs.abstract: Kay Gardner Bergl letter on Anne Roiphe's December 16 travel article, recalls working in Churchill's War Room during World War II and raises question about tunnel; Cabinet War Rooms director Phil Reed responds; photo

docs.snippet: A delegation from Norway met with the newly elected government in a first step to formalize a cease-fire with separatist Tamil rebels. Peace talks broke off almost seven years ago and Norway has been trying to revive them to resolve an 18-year con...
docs.lead_paragraph: A delegation from Norway met with the newly elected government in a first step to formalize a cease-fire with separatist Tamil rebels. Peace talks broke off almost seven years ago and Norway has been trying to revive them to resolve an 18-year conflict that has claimed more than 62,000 lives. The rebels have suggested that their chief negotiator be allowed to live in Madras, the capital of Tamil Nadu, in India, a tricky proposal because India has listed the Tigers as a terrorist group, as have Sri Lanka, the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia. The state rejected the suggestion yesterday, Agence France-Presse reported. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
docs.abstract: Norwegian delegation meets with Sri Lanka's newly elected government in first step to formalize cease-fire with separatist Tamil rebels (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Meeting On Peace Effort

docs.snippet: Talks on the country's political future could resume soon after the government and the two main rebel groups agreed yesterday to let political parties decide on their own representatives. The parties, which will influence the choice of the next pr...
docs.lead_paragraph: Talks on the country's political future could resume soon after the government and the two main rebel groups agreed yesterday to let political parties decide on their own representatives. The parties, which will influence the choice of the next president, are expected to draw up a new list of delegates over the weekend. The talks, scheduled to last 45 days, were suspended less than 24 hours after the opening ceremony on Monday because the rebel groups said the government had inserted stooges in the parties' delegations. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)
docs.abstract: Congo's two main rebel groups agree to let political parties select delegates to talks on country's political future (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Agreement Could Let Talks Resume
